    Unit Strengths, Weaknesses, and Basic Stats

    unit-strengths-weaknesses.Rmd

    1 Introduction

    Buying Battle Realms Zen Edition from Steam is one of the best game buys I have ever made. I still remember the few times I spent with the game in computer shops when I was in high school. I only played a few games, and I struggled to play, much more win, against the AI. I wish I could have played Battle Realms more back then.

    With the release of the game is steam, I never thought I would be able to have another chance to at least beat the AIs in the game. I am not that big of a fan of real time strategy games because I am not very good at micro-management, but Battle Realms has a certain appeal that makes want to be better at it.

    Since I am a returning noob to the game, I still am not very familiar to the different strengths and weaknesses of each unit. I know experience will let acquaint me with all the units, but that will take months, if not years, of playing and practice. Lucky for me, I know R and the Battle Realms data is accessible with the Battle Realms Data Editor. I took my knowledge and R and my love for Battle Realms to create this fun package.

    While there is an official Battle Realms unit chart, I think the information in it is incomplete especially for a noob and data lover like. Here is my attempt to provide enthusiasts with a way to review unit strengths and weaknesses. For non-useRs, you can go straight to the table.

    knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  collapse = TRUE,
  warning = FALSE,
  message = FALSE,
  comment = "#>"
)

library(battleRealms)
library(data.table)
library(cdata)
library(magrittr)
library(DT)

# create standard datatable function to be used in all tables in this post
show_datatable <- function(data) {
  data %>% 
    DT::datatable(
      rownames = FALSE,
      extensions = 'FixedColumns',
      options = list(
        pageLength = 50,
        scrollX = TRUE,
        scrollCollapse = TRUE,
        fixedColumns = list(leftColumns = 2),
        columnDefs = list(
          list(
            className = 'dt-center',
            targets = 0:(ncol(data) - 1)
          )
        )
      )
    )
}

    2 Data Preparation

    2.1 Select Variables

    
units <- br_units[
  ,
  .(
    UnitID = Type,
    Name,
    UnitClass,
    RiceTrainCost,
    WaterTrainCost,
    YinYangTrainCost,
    MaxHealth,
    HealthRecoveryRate,
    MaxHealthRecovery,
    MaxFatigue,
    FatigueRecovery,
    MeleeWeapon,
    MissileWeapon,
    MissileWeaponLaunchHeight,
    PrefersMelee,
    AMBlunt, 
    AMCutting, 
    AMExplosive,
    AMFire,
    AMMagical,
    AMPiercing,
    MaxUnitsAttacking,
    DeathYinYangAwarded,
    StaminaWhenRunning,
    Bracing,
    ImmuneToCharge,
    InnateAbility,
    BattleGear1,
    BattleGear2,
    BattleGear3
  )
]

weapons <- br_weapons[
  ,
  .(
    Type,
    BaseDamage,
    MinRange,
    MaxRange,
    MaxMountedRange,
    WatchtowerMinRange,
    WatchtowerMaxRange,
    Class,
    DamageClass,
    OpportunityFire,
    AreaOfEffect,
    Poison,
    PoisonTime,
    IsFireWeapon,
    FirePointDamage,
    YinPerHit,
    YangPerHit
  )
]

    2.2 Transform Data

    
units <- pivot_to_blocks(
  units,
  nameForNewKeyColumn = "WeaponType",
  nameForNewValueColumn = "WeaponID",
  columnsToTakeFrom = c("MeleeWeapon", "MissileWeapon")
)

setDT(units)

    2.3 Combine Unit and Weapons Data

    
unit_stats <- units[
  weapons,
  on = c("WeaponID" = "Type"),
  nomatch = 0,
  allow.cartesian = TRUE
]

    3 Data Showcase

    
# Make Damage Class more meaningful

unit_stats[
  ,
  DamageClass := fcase(
    DamageClass == 1, "Cutting"
  )
]

# Transform melee and missile damage in separate columns looks better for display
unit_stats <- pivot_to_rowrecs(
  unit_stats,
  columnToTakeKeysFrom = "WeaponType",
  columnToTakeValuesFrom = "BaseDamage",
  rowKeyColumns = c("UnitID", "Name")
)

# Rename weapon damage columns to be clearer
setnames(
  unit_stats, 
  old = c("MeleeWeapon", "MissileWeapon"), 
  new = paste0(c("MeleeWeapon", "MissileWeapon"), "Damage")
)



show_datatable(
  unit_stats
)

    Figure 3.1: Battle Realms Zen Edition Units and Some of Their Useful Stats.

    These data is available in the package as the br_unit_stats.
